Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The phone pressed to my ear, I rattled off my pitch, eyes flicking to the clock. It was the last day of the quarter, and I was three sales short of my target. My manager’s words echoed in my mind—no bonus, maybe even penalties, if we didn’t make it. I dialed again, voice tight with urgency, when the building alarm blared, shrill and insistent. Through the window, I saw water swirling at the curb, rising fast. The city’s emergency alert flashed on my phone: evacuate immediately, help neighbors if possible. My heart pounded. As a citizen, I knew I should check on Mrs. Lee next door, who lived alone and moved slowly. But as a telemarketer, I needed every second to close those last deals. The office buzzed with panic and ringing phones. I gripped the receiver, torn between the demands of my job and the responsibility to my community, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, waiting for me to choose.
